items.title: Regression in 0.4.7
items.body: Adding the `--verbose` as a common argument to all commands (introduced here: https://github.com/pyviz-dev/pyct/blob/master/pyct/cmd.py#L388) seems to be breaking the `fetch_data` command:  https://travis-ci.org/github/holoviz/datashader/jobs/703351542#L2541

items.title: Replace custom finding of examples at runtime with standard lib
items.body:
Currently I think we use code taken from holoviews originally, but seems like
https://importlib-resources.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ might be uncontroversial now as it's in the standard lib (of some recent python version) and exists as backported standalone packages for older ones?

items.title: Clean up the user experience
items.body:
Using pyctdev locally is one of the main goals of pyctdev, and it does work. However, the interface is awkward and not suitable for humans. And it contains many historical options. Additionally, with changes to things like conda env stacking etc over its lifetime, there are some sharp edges. So it's not ready for innocent users yet.

Docs to consolidate and fix up:
* https://github.com/pyviz/pyct/wiki/Using-pyctdev
* https://github.com/pyviz/pyct/wiki/Travis-caching
* https://github.com/pyviz/pyct/wiki/PyViz-project-release-procedure
* https://github.com/pyviz/pyctdev/blob/master/instructions.md

items.title: move pyctdev into this repository
items.body:
I tried this in the past as requested, but I encountered technical problems (maybe with autover, but I can't remember now) and had to move on.

I don't see the problem with two repositories, but I also have no issue with them both being in one repository. However the repository is organized, though, I think they do need to be separate python packages.

pyct: build and run time dependency of projects to package examples, provide user commands for examples/data, and possibly more things like that in the future. pyct is like autover in terms of when it's needed (package build, run time), and who needs it (packagers using any tool that uses setup.py, users, developers) - although pyct's optional, whereas autover is not.

pyctdev: maintainer/developer command line tool to perform common project maintenance tasks, including testing and packaging. Uses/depends on external tools to perform the tasks (e.g. conda and conda build and anaconda client, pip and tox and twine, pytest/nose, and so on).

items.title: Release pyctdev 0.6
items.body:
* [ ] interaction between package testing and package name support
* [ ] interaction between multiple packages (e.g. gv) and package name support
* [ ] interaction between existing recipe and recipe template
* [ ] ...

items.title: Shouldn't require datasets.yml to exist for the 'examples' command
Recent pyctdev release appears to have broken existing pip package upload commands
Include license file in packages
a minimal project description on pypi.org ?
Consider uploading tar.gz to PyPI
items.body:
There are pros and cons to .zip and .tar.gz but the latter 1) is the default on linux and mac (but not windows) 2) what we have generally been using so far.

Switching to .zip would mean updating all our conda-forge recipes which get the source archive from PyPI. For these reasons, I would considering forcing upload as .tar.gz even if it might make it trickier for windows users who don't have the suitable decompression software.

items.title: Skip data/ when copying examples?
items.body:
> I tried to build datashader's docs, but my disk ran out of room when copying the examples.  Turns out that it was copying all of the contents of examples/, which in my case included hundreds of gigabytes of data (some of which is needed to build the docs):

```
def examples(path='datashader-examples', verbose=False, force=False, root=__file__):
    """
    Copies the notebooks to the supplied path.
    """
    filepath = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(root))
    example_dir = os.path.join(filepath, './examples')
    if not os.path.exists(example_dir):
        example_dir = os.path.join(filepath, '../examples')
    if os.path.exists(path):
        if not force:
            print('%s directory already exists, either delete it or set the force flag' % path)
            return
        shutil.rmtree(path)
    ignore = shutil.ignore_patterns('.ipynb_checkpoints', '*.pyc', '*~')
    tree_root = os.path.abspath(example_dir)
    if os.path.isdir(tree_root):
        shutil.copytree(tree_root, path, ignore=ignore, symlinks=True)
    else:
        print('Cannot find %s' % tree_root)



def package_assets(example_path):
    """
    Generates pseudo-packages for the examples directory.
    """
    examples(example_path, force=True, root=__file__)
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk(example_path):
        walker(root, dirs+files)
    setup_args['packages'] += packages
    for p, exts in extensions.items():
        if exts:
            setup_args['package_data'][p] = exts
```

For now, I turned `data/` into a symlink, but it seems like we should only be packaging up files that are actually in git, and not gratuitously copying the entire filesystem?

items.title: Test commands for conda packages are executing in unexpected order
items.body: Need to address https://github.com/conda/conda-build/issues/2821, or adopt an alternative way of having conda build test a package in multiple different environments. (Currently the tox.ini is translated into a series of `conda-build -t` commands.)

Ensure pyviz websites are up

Jim: "make sure that all our websites are basically still up and running, a few times a day"

Maybe something like https://www.pingdom.com/free or https://uptimerobot.com/

items.title: Cache miniconda installations on travis?
items.body:
I.e. for each build, $HOME/miniconda would be extracted from the cache, then conda install dependencies would run (which will only update things that have changed), then the cache would be updated.

In many ways, this could be a better test than installing from scratch, since most users will be updating existing conda installations/environments rather than starting from scratch.

Installing miniconda and dependencies from scratch every time takes up a lot of the total build time for many projects (particularly the smaller projects).
